bioghist.p: The Schuylkill Navigation Company was chartered in 1815 to build a series of navigation improvements in the Schuylkill River. A 108-mile waterway was completed in 1827 linking Philadelphia to Port Carbon in the anthracite coal fields above Pottsville, Pennsylvania. During the 1860s the canal entered a period of decline. In 1869 it was damaged by a flood. Surrendering to the competition in 1870, the Schuylkill Navigation Company leased its waterway to the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad for a period of 979 years. Under the railroad's control, the Schuylkill Navigation continued to decline. Since the Delaware and Raritan Canal was owned by the competing Pennsylvania Railroad, Schuylkill boats were denied access to this important New Jersey waterway. As a result, traffic on the Schuylkill decreased rapidly. By 1890 only 144,994 tons of cargo passed through the Schuylkill Navigation. The Schuylkill Navigation was also greatly hindered by the problems of coal silt deposits which made its upper sections almost unusable. By 1891 the portion of Navigation above Port Clinton was abandoned. By 1904 the anthracite traffic had almost completely ceased, and after 1913 only an occasional cargo passed between Port Clinton and Philadelphia.

scopecontent.p: One volume of records of the Schuylkill Canal Transportation Line. Volume includes: lists of canal barges, with captain, address, year built, builder, where wintered and notes; list of letters sent, 1874; list of discharged captains, 1873. Includes reason for discharge; a list of captains who quit dishonorably, 1874; lists of damages and collisions, 1872-1875. Includes notes about the incidents and costs of repairs; Engineer's Department charges for assistance and repairs to boats, 1874-1875; and a list of P&R RR Co. officers for 1874. The cover of the volume is inscribed "G.T. Philips, Boat Agent, Office Schuylkill Canal Transportation Line, Fairmount Locks, Philadelphia, PA. P & R RR Co."
